column7: Comment Text

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Alice

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

In order to maintain a level playing field between huge content creators and little guys like myself Net Neutrality rules MUST remain in place and be rigorously enforced. ISPs should remain classified as Title II common carriers. Anything less is completely unacceptable. It is not government overreach, it is for the good of the American consumer (and creator.)

Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again?  Data is datn no matter where it comes from it should all be treated equal no matter if it is Facebook or Netflix.  Please don't change the way the ISP are regulated.  I can not afford to pay more for my internet just to watch Hutu, YouTube and Netflix.  I am afraid if the classification is changed the ISP will charge more for the ability to use the sites and many more.  

Thanks for your time
A Very Concerned citizen

Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Alex Clark

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. The importance of net neutrality cannot be understated. Imagine if car manufacturers were the ones who decided what roads could be used and when. That would be absolutely overruled by any reasonable human. Let's not make a mistake we can't come back from. Thank you for giving me the chance to speak out on such a serious issue, and for reading my comment.

Net Neutrality should be maintained and any attempt to eliminate this basic precept of fairness is not letting the "market work" but selling out to the big ISPs and telecom companies. Internet should remain a utility for all as it is in Europe and not something to game. It is essential for business all across the U.S. I strongly oppose Ajit Pai's efforts to erase this consumer friendly ruling.

This is not entirely an automated submission. i read through this letter before sending this, and i agree with every single sentiment expressed in it. I am a high school student, novice coder, computer enthusiast, all around nerd, and much more. 
To allow the FCC to repeal net neutrality would be devastating to my generation. We would not be able to make choice about content consumed, how much we pay for it, and much more! 
In fact, the only ISP in my area of Seattle is Comcast. If Comcast wanted us to vote a certain way on a referendum or measure, they could manipulate what we saw online, prevent us from viewing information that  may not support or even may show that their view could be completely to their benefit! 
If Comcast wanted us to pay them to watch Netflix, which we already pay for, they could block the site or throttle (slow down the connection) it to the point that we have to pay to make it usable. This would allow Comcast to charge whatever they wanted just to let us use simple services!
Before I end this, i would like to offer you, Patty Murray and Maria Cantwell, the ability to use this in a speech or anything to convince others to support this position. I would also be willing to make a speech of my own if the opportunity was presented to me. Another final word of advice: to the representative that claimed that "you don't need the internet", challenge him to perform all of his necessary duties as a representative without using any cell phone, internet connected computer, or tablet for a month. To transfer data or talk, he would have to use a landline, federal mail services, or a thumb drive. If he cannot do that for a month, he has proved that we need the internet.
Thank you,
-Sam Kallick

 To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.
 
 To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.
 
 To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 
 
 I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
 Philip Beyer

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Coltan

It is my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action, and believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: * deliberately throttling internet traffic * squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps * misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet * giving privileged treatment to companies they own * strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet * avoiding real competition at all costs Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

I'm worried that the current protections in place will be either weakened or some even fully removed if we change the way these protections are enforced. I would support a new regulation style if it guarantees the same, or better, protections that are in place now, but not if we lose any.  \n\nIn addition, Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past, Internet service providers have, on record, throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn't it possible that the Internet service providers, once again, would throttle these types of content and plausibly more? With streaming services becoming more and more mainstream, content throttling would devastate customer satisfaction towards both the Internet service providers and the streaming services. To add, if Internet service providers are not held to regulation of throttling content, as they currently are, innovation of Internet infrastructure  may continue to slow as there would be no incentive to improve the infrastructure to provide better speeds to customers.

Net Neutrality is frequently touted as a barrier to competition by those who misunderstand it. What Net Neutrality does protects smaller competitors and consumers from utility like internet companies. 

Do you want your electricity company to know how you use your appliances? Do you want them to be able to charge you, based on agreements they have with specific manufacturers? Is it healthy for the competition for big businesses to limit the amount of power you can use on products that aren't theirs?

If you answered no to any of these, then you should protect Net Neutrality. Stand against the Restoring Internet Freedom proposal. This is deception that we haven't seen the likes of since the Patriot Act of 2001. 

If you want to preserve internet freedom and foster competition, vote AGAINST this proposal. Protect Net Neutrality.

I just want to have my internet. Allowing a connection to other computers to be charged other than for maintaining the networks seems lavish to me, now to make that connection worth a premium is just wrong. The internet was made for communication and to limit the worlds most open source of information is indirectly a restriction on freedom of press and speech.

Removing the policies that this agency, FCC, had approved under the last administrator would negatively affect the consumers in regards to how internet service providers operate.  This agency, FCC, needs to be working to increase competitiveness in the internet service provider landscape.  If you want to do something, maybe enforcing what was supposed to happen in regards to the telecommunications act of 1996.  Thank you for reading my comment.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Jakeb Woodward

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I stand firmly against this proposal. Preserving net neutrality is imperative to the free market. Allowing telecom companies to have it their way would have massive repercussions that would affect everyone, from competitors to consumers - sans, of course, telecom companies and anti-neutrality politicians. Without the Title II rules and regulations, telecom corporations are given unchecked power and control over their customers' Internet access; there would be nothing to stop Comcast, for example, from throttling competitors by placing additional charges on their services or blocking their sites entirely in order to extort money from their customers. The American consumer stands to gain absolutely nothing by supporting this proposal. It is anti-neutrality, anti-free market, and anti-consumer. It does not promote the rights of consumers, it gives telecom companies to ability to unfairly crush competition whilst shafting their customers in the process. As such, I strongly disapprove of this proposal, and urge the FCC to reconsider its priorities in promoting corporate interests as opposed to those of its constituents.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

It is my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action and believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: * deliberately throttling internet traffic * squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps * misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet * giving privileged treatment to companies they own * strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet * avoiding real competition at all costs Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication. Thank you for reading my comment.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Bottom line up front, I'm worried that the 2015 protections will be rolled away in favor of companies and not the consumers/users.  ISPs have mentioned a return to the 2010 Open Internet Order, which favored ISPs regarding technicalities in official name/service.  ISPs were held to rules/regulations but were not officially considered Common Carriers, thus allowing courts to favor ISPs based on arbitrary gray area (via official name/category) and the FCC losing.  That's an illusion of consumer protection that isn't justified to anybody but the respective companies running the internet.  Based on previous behavior from ISPs and throttling content based on their own determination of what was lawful or not, why wouldn't they do it again once the 2015 Title II designation is gone?  The buck stops with the FCC to keep consumers protected in practice, not as an illusion.  Thanks for reading my comment.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Matt Beyer

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Anas

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules. I am firmly against this action. I believe the incentives of ISPs would not be well-aligned with the interests of the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, and lobbying cities and state governments to prevent municipalities from giving their residents high-speed internet. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. I also believe the main argument for undoing net neutrality--that it will encourage innovation--is completely untrue. Saying an open internet will hinder innovation in technology is like saying publicly subsidized drinkable tap water is a hindrance to food and beverage innovation. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication (not to mention America's position as the best place in the world in which to start a company).

We need to defend the freedom of the Internet. We need to maintain the neutrality, data is data and as such it should be treated equally no matter what the content is or who owns it. 

In other countries throttling and zero rating are are already changing behaviors and altering how people navigate the Internet. In some cases Zero rating for Facebook, Whatsapp or Twitter keeps people consuming only those applications and not even considering browsing the Internet for more information, as they don't have the incentive to spend money and leave the mentioned services.

It's also not fair that some companies can prioritize their content because they have plenty of money while thousands of startups or small businesses get less speed or bandwidth because of their condition; that's a new source of inequality that we can't allow.

Telecom and cable broadband corporations just want to profit over the Internet with the new model proposed, well guess what, no thank you. They are already slowing you down with nonsense data caps (not existing in the past). They raise your prices unilaterally for no reason (did it to me twice in one year to reach a 33% increase of my data plan).

They are already making tons of money and Just look at the data: USA's broadband speed doesn't even make top 10 in the world. However the prices are some of the most expensive ones. Internet access: Almost 80 million people in the US don't have access according to World Bank Data 2015 (26% of the country). If they really want to make good business, increase their consumer base and ARPU, be creative, innovate, but not on the Internet neutrality and customers' expense.

I'm a Trump supporter, but I'm deeply disturbed by this attack on net neutrality. Capitalism only functions when there's a free market with real competition, which doesn't exist in the telecom industry. My preferred solution would be to use anti-trust laws to break these monopolies up and give new companies a chance to compete. However, failing that, net neutrality laws are the only option for preventing them from abusing their power and influence. Just because I supported Trump in one election doesn't necessarily mean I'll support him in the next one. Do right.

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Adriane Baade

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
shechter.g@gmail.com

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

As if the current broadband monopoly weren't enough to bleed us consumers financially dry, you (the FCC) want to add insult to injury by proposing this monstrosity? The current monopolistic practices of American ISP companies damages the economy and hurts consumers. The lack of competition allows them to raise rates, sell personal data, and now potentially charge companies for access to their customer base. This will cause degraded service for the consumer and has the potential to devastate small businesses and tech startups. If the spirit of American entrepreneurship and innovation is to continue into the modern era, internet access must be treated as an essential utility instead of a method for wringing additional profits out of homes and businesses. For these reasons I strongly oppose this proposal.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Calling this proposal "Restoring Internet Freedom" is a travesty, a blatant lie designed to wrap up cronyism with a star-spangled shroud. The internet is already plenty free. What this proposal aims to do is give ISPs and huge media corporations the ability to lock up the internet behind pay walls and throttled speeds, all designed to make users pay more for a service they already get today.

This will not boost "internet freedom." It will only generate profits for the corps at the direct costs of the consumers. Pretending it is anything else is the worst kind of lie. ISPs have already shown, in legal testimony even, that they are ready and willing to bend rules to limit speeds of competition, establish monopolistic market policies, and screw over paying customers time and time again. By deregulating the consumer protections in place - currently called 'net neutrality' - you will open the door for all these abuses to run unchecked. This will destroy the market and directly harm the consumer. If you even pretend to care about internet freedom and equality, you'll drop this proposal like the steaming pile of bull that it so clearly is.

I hope you hear the voice of common sense here, and abandon this plan to give a bunch of unethical companies the chance to do whatever they like without oversight. they aren't to be trusted, and honestly, if the FCC plans to allow this sort of abuse, neither should you.

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Hudson

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Johan Alvarez

Net Neutrality is important as all sites on the Internet should be treated equally. I'm concerned that changes to the current classification could harm the equality of sites on the Internet -- as all sites should be able to be accessed freely without any throttling or censorship. I'm also very worried that ISPs or mobile companies or Internet providers may try to throttle sites and force them to pay them extra fees to get basic service for Internet usage. That's discrimination -- as all sites should have equal access to the Internet and not have to pay extra fees for their site to be able to load at all. Do not take away our protections regarding Internet and Net Neutrality. Do not give in to rich corporations that wish to destroy the freedom on the Internet for profit. Focus on our protections within Net Neutrality and keep them intact please.

Mr Pai

I find it absolutely appalling that you are trying to abolish American citizen's freedom of information on the Internet. Selling our freedom to big corporations is absolutely unacceptable. There's something called the first amendment in this country, and if you allow corporations such as these to take over our freedom of information, what does that say about our democracy, our freedom and our Constitution? We have all seen the effects of this monopoly in the mainstream media, which has now been sold down the river to six big corporations.  Choosing profits over people is about as undemocratic as you can get. I don't know how you can sit as the head of the FCC and pretend that you believe in democracy, whilst trying to sell Americans freedom of information to the highest bidder.  Your brand of capitalism will never survive in this country, and it is currently a dying system, because if you have people who do not have jobs, and do not have income, how are they supposed to spend money to grow the economy & buy the products these corporations are selling?
You take away these freedoms and allow these corporations to charge anything they desire for our Internet, then people simply will not purchase it. Every time something gets privatized and the prices get excessively raised, people just stop buying. What you and your DC bubble, and big corporations, do not seem to understand, is that the people in this country (50% of which are living as poor or in poverty), simply will not be able to afford the services if sold off to a few big corporations.  I suggest you leave net neutrality alone, and stop trying to come up with new ways to destroy the average American. I guarantee that if you bothered to ask the American people what they want, they would strongly oppose your proposal and chose net neutrality any day of the week.

It is my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action, and believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: * deliberately throttling internet traffic * squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps * misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet * giving privileged treatment to companies they own * strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet * avoiding real competition at all costs Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Net Neutrality is very important. The current rules that classify ISP's as Title II utilities is sufficient to protect Net Neutrality. Please do not change the rules for the ISPs. This proposed change will make it legal for them to discriminate and "throttle" some types of internet tracking. This will open the door for them to categorize and segregate internet traffic into packages and force consumers and companies to pay more for various types of content. This will harm consumers. If you use the internet at all, you should not want this personally. It will negatively effect your experience along with everyone else. Even if you do not use the internet, you have an obligation to protect the American people from the tyranny of a few large, powerful companies. This proposed change is very, very bad. Please do not do it.

I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Joseph

Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. Most concerning is what appears to be the callous, disingenuous or at worst naive approach that this proposal has been voiced. Those that are responsible to protect the common good should think about the legacy we are leaving our children. I implore you to be honest in protecting consumers. Competition keeps us strong and stable. Monopolies have historically served only the few and fed the worst of human traits, greed. Please do the right thing. Thank you for reading my comment.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
William Dunnam

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

I am concerned that the consumer protections that are put in place will not be enforced over time. My home location is dominated by two major ISPs with high cost plans. Based off of the reasoning made from recent decisions, I do not see greater broadband availability occurring with privacy protections being reduced.  I see this as a greater risk of secure personal information being disclosed and a reinforcement of  current stagnant broadband distribution. I would support a system in place that holds at least the same standard of regulation and adapts to new developments in technology.

This is not entirely an automated submission. i read through this letter before sending this, and i agree with every single sentiment expressed in it. I am a high school student, novice coder, computer enthusiast, all around nerd, and much more. 
To allow the FCC to repeal net neutrality would be devastating to my generation. We would not be able to make choice about content consumed, how much we pay for it, and much more! 
In fact, the only ISP in my area of Seattle is Comcast. If Comcast wanted us to vote a certain way on a referendum or measure, they could manipulate what we saw online, prevent us from viewing information that  may not support or even may show that their view could be completely to their benefit! 
If Comcast wanted us to pay them to watch Netflix, which we already pay for, they could block the site or throttle (slow down the connection) it to the point that we have to pay to make it usable. This would allow Comcast to charge whatever they wanted just to let us use simple services!
Before I end this, i would like to offer you, Patty Murray and Maria Cantwell, the ability to use this in a speech or anything to convince others to support this position. I would also be willing to make a speech of my own if the opportunity was presented to me. Another final word of advice: to the representative that claimed that "you don't need the internet", challenge him to perform all of his necessary duties as a representative without using any cell phone, internet connected computer, or tablet for a month. To transfer data or talk, he would have to use a landline, federal mail services, or a thumb drive. If he cannot do that for a month, he has proved that we need the internet.
Thank you,
-Sam Kallick

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Justin

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

I want to register my strong support of the FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality) and my vehement opposition to any measures to dismantle or weaken them. An open and accessible internet is vital if the US wishes to maintain its economic position in the future. A restricted internet will strangle the many small businesses which depend on online transactions and will have a chilling effect on entrepreneurship and technological innovation. Furthermore, the internet has become a vital public platform for social interaction. Allowing service providers to price-gate internet access will create and exacerbate social divides and inequalities. The move to damage net neutrality is badly out of tune with the future we're headed towards, and if enacted, will severely damage the US' stake in that future. If anything, I believe the consumer protection afforded by net neutrality should be strengthened and expanded.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Andrew Vong

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Mihir Bajaj

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. Thanks for reading my comment.

Net Neutrality is frequently touted as a barrier to competition by those who misunderstand it. What Net Neutrality does protects smaller competitors and consumers from utility like internet companies. 

Do you want your electricity company to know how you use your appliances? Do you want them to be able to charge you, based on agreements they have with specific manufacturers? Is it healthy for the competition for big businesses to limit the amount of power you can use on products that aren't theirs?

If you answered no to any of these, then you should protect Net Neutrality. Stand against the Restoring Internet Freedom proposal. This is deception that we haven't seen the likes of since the Patriot Act of 2001. 

If you want to preserve internet freedom and foster competition, vote AGAINST this proposal. Protect Net Neutrality.

Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Patrick

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

It is my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action, and believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: * deliberately throttling internet traffic * squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps * misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet * giving privileged treatment to companies they own * strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet * avoiding real competition at all costs Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Aidan

I believe a free and open internet is essential to our democracy.  Free access to information by the public is one of our great treasures- we have the best library system in the world.  I see the internet as a natural extension of this.  All of us- rich  and poor need access to information to make informed decisions. Please don't make the internet into a playground for the rich and powerful.  Please support net neutrality. Thanks

I strongly support net neutrality. You speak of reducing government control of the internet by reducing regulations but you do not say that your proposal gives more control to Corporations. The FCCs duty is to protect the Consumer, not Corporations. The FCC should protect net neutrality. Do not give more power and control to Corporations which control access to free-flowing information. Internet access is a necessity and consumers fair access to it should be protected by the FCC. Internet access should not be monopolized, price-jacked or chosen by internet providers. Do not allow service provider Corporations (which already have a monopoly or limited competition in many areas) prioritize certain distributors over others for their own profits. Please keep net neutrality.

I am writing to express my opposition to the rollback of net neutrality laws. I agree wholeheartedly with the many organizations who wrote to Commission Chairman Pai and US Senators Thune and Nelson in March: "Protecting net neutrality is crucial to ensuring that the internet remains a central driver of economic growth and opportunity, job creation, education, free expression, and civic organizing for everyone. The principles of net neutrality – that all data on the internet should be treated equally, and internet service providers (ISPs) should not discriminate or provide preference to any data, regardless of its source, content, or destination – are the foundation that has made the internet the engine of opportunity it is today. The continuation of net neutrality is essential to the continued growth of the country and to ensuring access to social, political, and economic empowerment for all."

We should be working to ensure that everyone throughout the United States has easy, equal, and affordable access to the internet, which has become an indispensable part of modern life. Part of that includes allowing startups and other small businesses to compete on equal footing with larger, established companies. Equal access to these freedoms is a large reason the United States has so many successful internet-based companies. Squashing this innovation would be harmful for both small business owners and for the economy in general. I believe it also goes against the core values of freedom of expression and equality of access that have made the United States great.

Thank you!

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Glenn

Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Alex

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. Thanks for reading my comment.\n\nI’m worried that the protections that are in place will be weakened if we change the way they’re enforced. I would support a new regulation style if it guarantees the same or better protections, but not if we lose any.

Net Neutrality is frequently touted as a barrier to competition by those who misunderstand it. What Net Neutrality does protects smaller competitors and consumers from utility like internet companies. 

Do you want your electricity company to know how you use your appliances? Do you want them to be able to charge you, based on agreements they have with specific manufacturers? Is it healthy for the competition for big businesses to limit the amount of power you can use on products that aren't theirs?

If you answered no to any of these, then you should protect Net Neutrality. Stand against the Restoring Internet Freedom proposal. This is deception that we haven't seen the likes of since the Patriot Act of 2001. 

If you want to preserve internet freedom and foster competition, vote AGAINST this proposal. Protect Net Neutrality.

This action is unacceptable.  Internet communication crosses state lines and falls squarely into the jurisdiction and responsibility of the FCC.  There is no viable or responsible reason to change the current status of the internet.  There is no reasonable or responsible reason that anyone other than the end user has access to their browsing history either.
