Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
brett

As an IT professional, I oppose any efforts to undo net neutrality rules. ISPs have basically become a cartel, they agree not to compete with each other in many municipalities which means that at most tiers offering speeds higher than DSL there is little to no competition in most markets. 

Additionally, many of the largest ISPs have extremely high profit margins, the internet is not a quantifiable commodity like oil or other consumables, Time Warner Cable had a 97% profit margin on high-speed internet service in 2013, I don't see that they're in need of additional revenue streams to make internet service a lucrative business. 

Customers use their internet service like a phone line to communicate and conduct business with 3rd parties. Like the telephone system was the major mode of commerce and communication for much of the 1900s, the internet is in the 2000s; it makes sense to regulate ISPs as common carriers.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.
Refer to Attachment(s).

I stand firmly against this proposal. Preserving net neutrality is imperative to the free market. Allowing telecom companies to have it their way would have massive repercussions that would affect everyone, from competitors to consumers - sans, of course, telecom companies and anti-neutrality politicians. Without the Title II rules and regulations, telecom corporations are given unchecked power and control over their customers' Internet access; there would be nothing to stop Comcast, for example, from throttling competitors by placing additional charges on their services or blocking their sites entirely in order to extort money from their customers. The American consumer stands to gain absolutely nothing by supporting this proposal. It is anti-neutrality, anti-free market, and anti-consumer. It does not promote the rights of consumers, it gives telecom companies to ability to unfairly crush competition whilst shafting their customers in the process. As such, I strongly disapprove of this proposal, and urge the FCC to reconsider its priorities in promoting corporate interests as opposed to those of its constituents.

At many points in my life, I have lived in places where I had only ONE option for internet providers.  Additionally, there have been many points in my life when internet access was a gamechanger -- for finding a job, for finding medical information or providers, for staying in touch with friends and family, etc.  In fact, these days I do nearly everything on the internet -- as do most people!

Allowing internet companies to limit individual access to the internet would be a horrible blow for our society -- both on a practical level and on a ethical level.  On a practical level, it would limit many people's access to necessary services.  On an ethical level, it would severely diminish free speech and the exchange of valuable ideas.

Save Net Neutrality!

The internet has grown to become a necessity in the lives of most Americans and, similar to other government-regulated utilities (like water and power), should be treated as a basic need. If broadband innovation has been "stifled", this is the fault of broadband companies wasting tax payer money earmarked for building up the fiber infrastructure in this country. These companies have regional monopolies and there is little to no competition forcing consumers to pay a premium. Power companies cannot block or throttle your electricity if they believe you are using it frivolously - likewise with water. Additionally, they cannot double bill both a company and a consumer for the same connection. The United States lags behind most first-world nations in their implementation of a full-fiber network and allowing these ISPs to continue charging excessively without innovating will cause economic damage and make it difficult for American citizens and businesses to compete globally and locally. Please implement the Title II classification and net neutrality guidelines placed by the Obama/Wheeler administration and help bring this country's infrastructure into the future.

The internet is absolutely a utility and needs to be treated as such. Broadband is not merely an information service, it is a telecommunications service. ISPs are Absolutely common carriers under Title II. Further, market-based policies do not work when something is either a monopoly or a necessity. The internet is both. ISPs function as oligopolies, by dividing up the U.S., they function as a monopoly. The internet is used for entertainment, employment networking, banking, news, socializing; in short, it is a necessity to participate in modern society. The elimination of the classification of the internet as a utility would do nothing but profit the telecommunications companies, while restricting access to the average person. The ironic misnomer of "Restoring Internet Freedom" would do exactly the opposite.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Brian Morris

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Dir Sir or Madam -

17-108 is a terrible plan and will serve to make the Internet less useful, less usable, and less of a transforming force than it could or should be.

I have been a professional network engineer engaged in building and maintaining the Internet since 1993, working with groups ranging from startup companies to Fortune 100 companies; for a time, several of the largest websites in the world were hosted on networks I maintained.  So I speak with substantial knowledge of how the Internet works, and moreover why it works.  I have been involved in questions of how traffic should get routed and worked to make that happen, and I've seen the balance between business and technical decisions.  

One of the things that helped foster the telephone system, which powered the growth of the United States in business and as a country, was the idea that telephone networks should be "common carriers" - for the internet, this concept is called "net neutrality".  And 17-108 will destroy it and lead to a broken Internet that will be worse for consumers.

Thank you for your consideration in this matter.

Regards,

Regis M. Donovan
Network Engineer

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Joshua Olson

This is liberty and freedom that you're tarnishing. We will utilize democracy to loudly voice our dissatisfaction. If you proceed with your proposals with a vote, you will face immense grassroots resistance even if you ignore us. We won't stop until this injustice is quelled. Don't touch our internet. * Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Daniel Weimer

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

It is my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action, and believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: * deliberately throttling internet traffic * squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps * misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet * giving privileged treatment to companies they own * strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet * avoiding real competition at all costs Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Travis Watters

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me and to America as a whole. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopolistic power to stand between Americans and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. We will be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier. This is extortion, and it should not be government sanctioned and funded. The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in the way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with American's ability to access what they want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

Net Neutrality and the freedom it protects are vital to America. Solid infrastructure is necessary to a healthy economy. It allows growth and innovation, and keeps us competitive on the world stage. Losing it poses a threat to America's economic well-being. Internet Service Providers (and those who fund/support them) will be able to pick and chose winners in the market by denying them access to customers and removing their ability to communicate and coordinate. This is the exact opposite of a free market. We lose the benefits of competition and gain nothing but negativity. They will be able to control access to news and resources. They will censor critics. They will strangle those who do not agree to their terms. Politicians will be able to silence opposition by helping/paying these service providers. The politicians that do this may be your opposition. Even worse, they may win with these corrupt tactics. Losing Net Neutrality is signing away our freedom and economic well-being. Supporting the push to end it is putting short term gain for a few over the health of this nation.

As a constituent and an American who cares for the future of my country, I will be watching the results of these votes. I cannot, and will not, in good conscious support any politician who throws away their sacred duty to represent my and my fellow American's best interests. I will vote against you. I will explain the issues and urge everyone that I can to actively vote against you. I will directly support and fund your competition that does represent me in whatever ways I can. As an American I can not and will not sit idly by, and I pray that you will do the same.

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Nicholas Welch

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Ben Sanecki

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Aaron Bottegal

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Matthew Kauth

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Whenever the word 'freedom' is invoked in the name of something, you immediately understand that it deserves twice as much suspicion as would otherwise be required and this is indeed the case here. An unfettered internet wherein all data is treated equally has the virtue of protecting everyone from the largest to the smallest of businesses and the most profligate or intermittent of users. One in which rates can be set according to payment or throttled to favour a particular business or service lacks that virtue and it seems ingenuous to suggest that it would continue to provide the even, open service we enjoy today. Support Net Neutrality and reject this pernicious effort to turn freedom of information into just another paid commodity.

Title II classification is important to ensure that the FCC is able to properly regulate internet service providers. I DO NOT support docket 17-108 or any other attempt to move ISP's away from their current Title II classification.

The internet should be free for all

Net Neutrality is frequently touted as a barrier to competition by those who misunderstand it. What Net Neutrality does protects smaller competitors and consumers from utility like internet companies. 

Do you want your electricity company to know how you use your appliances? Do you want them to be able to charge you, based on agreements they have with specific manufacturers? Is it healthy for the competition for big businesses to limit the amount of power you can use on products that aren't theirs?

If you answered no to any of these, then you should protect Net Neutrality. Stand against the Restoring Internet Freedom proposal. This is deception that we haven't seen the likes of since the Patriot Act of 2001. 

If you want to preserve internet freedom and foster competition, vote AGAINST this proposal. Protect Net Neutrality.

Former Chairman Wheeler was right. Internet connectivity is a vital resource. This so called 'Freedom' legislation only means freedom for the ISPs. Freedom to throttle performance. Freedom to decide who gets the 'fast lane'. Freedom to decide who gets to take full advantage of a critical tool, and who gets crumbs.

Rep. Sensenbrenner showed how completely stuck in the 20th century he was when he opined "nobody needs the internet!". Clearly, he is blissfully unaware of the thousands of children being home schooled right here in WI for whom a speedy internet connection is essential. As a returning student myself, I can speak for how crucial my connection is.
Contrary to the position of the ISPs, a free and open internet is a vehicle for prosperity...prosperity for the people.
Revoking title II status is path to prosperity....or more simply rapacious profits....only for the telcos and ISPs

Revoking title II gives ISPs entirely too much power. This action's very title is a shameless deception.

The internet is as vital as electricity or the telephone. To pull the title II designation would be a heinous act.

I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Misty

Equal access to the Internet for all people of the United States of America should not be sacrificed to the mass market greed and capitalist endeavors of multi-billion dollar corporations whose bottom lines disregarded the well being of their customers long ago. Indeed, even now Internet service across the country varies in different regions, depending on what companies offer their services in a given area and what prices they choose to charge for varying broadband speeds. To give these companies further power to charge differing amounts or change download/upload speeds dependant on what sites their consumers visit is a gross misunderstanding of what the Internet is. The Internet is not a simple commodity that exists only for entertainment or to fully serve U.S. citizens with the largest wallets. It exists as a source of information and connection for all Americans. To put this in perspective, think of the students of America. When was the last time a child, young adult, or career-driven citizen was dependant solely on books to write a paper? A thesis? A dissertation? A proposal? To mandate that only the richest families in America should have unbridled access to the greatest educational tool of our time clearly serves to further segregate the population of the United States across class lines and further disintegrate our freedom. An informed populace is a freer populace. And what of the daughter of a U.S. military serviceman? Should she not be able to communicate with a father whose life is on the line overseas? Or should this irreplaceable bond between father and child be degraded because her mother—who works multiple jobs—had to choose between paying for heat in the winter or paying for greater access to video call services through her broadband provider, which only months before was "freely" included as part of an already exuberant subscription package? The Internet is a figurative (and perhaps literal) window to the world. Don't limit your citizens' ability to open that window due to their income, lest you make them desperate for air.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

This is a travesty; it is a selling-out of small internet business opportunity; it is a handover of control of the most important forms of media to large corporations which have very clear and specific agendas; it is the architecture of censorship. There are no circumstances under which this is justifiable public policy, and yet, you proceed so far anyway. Are you that ready - that _eager_ - to create this dystopian oligarchy? What is _wrong_ with you?

The net neutrality rules are essential for people in my industry to be able to create startups and compete with larger companies.  Removing the net neutrality rules will hinder competition and innovation in this country.  Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to: * Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees" * Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds) * Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating") Net neutrality is a consumer protection law that needs to remain in place, otherwise the internet service providers will begin to charge unfair wages depending on the website the customers are trying to reach.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Please read these words with an open mind, and truly think from an unbiased standpoint.  It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.  As someone who works in an industry centered around technology, I would ask one thing of those who fight against the true freedom of the internet.  The internet is already free, let's keep it that way!  Thank you for taking the time to read this through.  I hope you will look at this without only seeing the bad in the world.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Skyler reiman

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The internet and internet access should be classified as a utility, there should be no barriers to entry, there should be no gaming of the system. Shame on you, you are what is wrong with post industrial society, you cause more harm with your pen's than terrorists do with actual swords. You need to be held accountable for your barbarism.

Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication. Americans are quite limited in their choices for true high speed Internet access. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to: Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees", Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds), Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating"). They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way. Please don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Swapnil Patel

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
vicki

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I am strongly against the chairman's plan to rollback net neutrality/title II protections.  US ISP's have proven time and time again that they operate with impunity and minimal competition in a service (internet access) that is critical to many areas of modern life.  I worked at an ISP for 10 years, and they are in no way put in to some unfair disadvantage by net neutrality and title II.  In fact those protections are needed specifically because of the rhetoric and actions of those ISP's.  The US, which is the birthplace of the internet, is falling further and further behind other developed nations because the major ISP's are allowed to strong arm any potential competition, thus ensuring they can continue to raise prices on unchanged services with minimal future investment.  If this was solely a case of their network/their rules, that might be one thing, but US tax payers have contributed vast amounts of resources to allow these ISP's to build their networks through tax credits, service fees, grants, and favorable access rights.  The current rules as written still don't go far enough to protect citizens from predatory ISP's, but removing those protections will do significant harm to those least capable of defending themselves (the citizens).  I am strongly opposed to the weakening of net neutrality and removal of title II.  Voluntary promises from ISP's are a terrible idea, as history has proven time and time again.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Michael Arnold

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Matthew Malanga

Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. Thanks for reading my comment.

Lets go ahead and say you let this pass. What is to stop my provider from throttling my speeds because I'm watching netflix? ((Ala Comcast did back in 2015.)) I understand my privacy, and the privacy of americans online means nothing to you, But given the prominence of the internet being used for job applications, school work, and the ever important personal lives. Can you imagine every time you had to go check your emails there was an intentional throttling of your speeds to make it slow just to drive you into getting the "Super Fast XXMbps bundle" or the "Email special Speed package" from your isp? 

Then theres the cellphone providers, who say a plan is "Unlimited" and "High Speed" but are on record of thottling your speeds down after you go over a set amount that they set, or sites and services that aren't a part of their zero-rating network.

I know in this day and age its hard to imagine letting something be free without putting restrictions and regulations. but the internet needs to be free. Dont let money hungry ISPs have their way. Protect the internet. Thank you for reading my comment.

The idea that businesses will self-regulate and keep the interests of their customers at heart is patently absurd. At times, self-regulation may seem to appear, but the number of times when it occurs by design is infinitesimal. Time and again, history has shown us that the driving factor behind business is not people, nor even customers, but money. There is no reason to expect that internet service providers will work any differently. Please help ensure the freedom and free flow of information on and across the internet.
Refer to Attachment(s).

Look, cable companies cannot be trusted to regulate themselves when their sole interest is profit.  The internet today has grown far and beyond what it was in the early days.  The Title II classification was made necessary because certain large internet providers could no longer be trusted to maintain fairness in how they handle data, by attempting to prioritize the data of those who are wealthy enough to pay for special treatment.  This unfairly impacts small businesses and individual users who would use the internet's primary defining attribute and the biggest reason for its growth and impact: Free and open communication.   When I signed up for internet in Seattle several years ago, I had only one choice in provider.  The city was (and may still be) divided into regions which were assigned to different internet providers, much like a utility.  I literally had no way to choose who I did business with.   This argument that regulation wasn't needed when the internet was young, and therefore isn't needed today is utter nonsense.   It is the FCC's job to ensure these near-monopolies operate on the level and do not abuse their power for profit.

PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE: Don't let him and the cable companies get through with their evil proposal to destroy our Internet.

Regards,  and please fight for the internet,

S
S Stewart

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Zachary Ellis

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

This bill is bad for consumers, and all about filling the pockets of companies we are paying for internet access.  It's name is a flat out lie.  This bill will allow the network provider to block sites, or redirect to someone who pays them to direct you to them, with no freedom at all.  New goods and services will be expected to pay to play, so not only will you pay to have net access, but the provider will have to pay to access you.  Increasing the amount of money we will have to pay to stream video, or buy goods, because the internet provider will want to charge them also, for what we the consumer have already paid for.  Not even the phone company could charge both parties for a long distance call, in the past.  Now this bill will allow your ISP the one you pay for it block your bank if thy don't like them, or if they refuse to pay... again for something you already pay for.  Maybe they will strike a deal and you will be limited to one store, so much for free market.   In many places we are limited to one ISP, we have only access to one highspeeen provider.  We will have no choice, and the FCC knows it, this bill proves they don't care.  Believe me we will rouste this government corruption and we will remove you from office, and hopefully extract damages against you personally for dereliction of duties.

The establishment of net neutrality rules was the best piece of legislature governing the internet to come out of the FCC ever.  The success of the internet lives and dies on the back of free, open, unrestricted, equal, and fair distribution of data, regardless of subject matter.  The current chairman's proposal to demolish these net neutrality rules are incredibly short sighted, unashamedly anti-consumer, and unarguably in favor of corporation protectionism.  Removing these net neutrality rules opens the doors for the proven untrustworthy and arguably "evil" ISP's (Internet Service Providers) to further exploit consumers while delivering sub-par service nation-wide.  The current chairman's arguments of the current rules 'stifling innovation and hurting jobs' are baseless and unfounded.  Innovations need to be made in delivering content faster, more efficiently, and with less cost.  A nation without net neutrality would let ISPs 'innovate' to create internet slow lanes & toll roads, with more fees and costs;  all of which many of the national and large regional ISPs have already attempted in the past.  The internet was created to allow more efficient exchange of information.  To allow the current ISPs to control and modify how that works is tantamount to censorship.  The internet should be open, free, unbiased, and fair.  As it was created, and as it should remain.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Daniel Kemp

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

keep the internet free with net neutrality.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC should keep the "Protecting and Promoting the Open Internet" rules passed in 2015 in place which prevent Internet Service Providers from Blocking, Throttling, and enacting Paid Prioritization of internet traffic. These regulations help to protect consumers and the public interest from private organizations which are eager to overcharge in an industry that already benefits from a lack of competition. Passing the "Restoring Internet Freedom" Act would be a step backwards and a vote against the interests of the citizens of the United States.

I am against 17-108, 17-108 does not serve the interest of the people, it serves the interest of corporations, which are not people. Anyone in favor of 17-108 either doesn't understand how the internet works or is working in the best interest of corporations, not actual American citizens.\n\nThe internet should remain open and neutral, any action to the contrary, such as any action taken by 17-108, promotes behavior that will limit free speech on the internet, i.e. a REDUCTION OF THE FREEDOM of Americans. Why would the United States government want to limit free speech?

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Andrew

I am not an American citizen. But I am deeply concerned for the entire world's access to the Internet as a result of this bill.

Removing measures that ensure the Internet's neutrality in terms of speed and access will cause access to much of the Internet to be at risk. Many servers, used for various purposes (websites, remote hosted backups, servers for apps etc) are hosted (ie physically located) in the USA.

If access to these servers are based on ISPs paying speeds for "fastlane" access for example, then users around the entire world will be affected. 

If a business based in the USA fails to access these "fastlane" services for any reason, then their business will be impacted.

If an end user from outside the US is trying to access such a service said business offers, that has been impacted in such a way, their experience will be impaired by that business' decision. They may try other sites, taking opportunity away from that business.

If the business we are talking about is a media organisation, this isolation will impact Freedom of the Press.

If the business is a technology company offering services, this will impact consumer choice.

If the business is a services firm operating in the US, this will impact the services the US can offer the world, and impact jobs, growth, innovation.

I call upon the FCC to reconsider this dire proposal, as it not only affects the USA, but the entire world.

I am very opposed to this proposed "Restoring Internet Freedom" plan. I want the FCC to regulate ISPs in a way that ensures that there is a level playing field for all internet users. By eliminating net neutrality and allowing big ISPs to prioritize some content over others does not make the internet more free, it makes it less.  As someone who depend on the internet for my research, often looking for obscure sources of information, having anyone placing restrictions on my internet use is an anathema. Please DO NOT change the net neutrality rules!!  I will also be writing my congress people to ensure that they do not change the laws governing ISPs.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Net neutrality is essential to a free and open internet. I do not want ISPs determining where I can surf and how much I have to pay to be able to have access to certain internet based services. I don't even know why this is a discussion. Who do you work for? The public or the corporations?

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.
