Do not kill Net Neutrality.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Ryan Turk

The FCC is currently taking public comments on the Net Neutrality debate. I 


It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

!

Internet service is most definitely a public utility, therefore I support net neutrality rules under title II. ISPs have too much market power, face little competition if any in areas they serve, and have a history of abusing their market power. ISPs must not be allowed to operate using our scarce resources without regulatory oversight. They are not trustworthy and have earned that reputation based on their past behavior. The FCC is foolish to think a hands off approach and voluntary restraint will prevent ISP businesses from abusing their enormous market power. The FCC must put aside its ideology and deal with the reality presented by past behavior and likelihood of the same going forward from ISPs. Do NOT be so naive that ISPs will self regulate. With NO rules in place they will abuse the market. Period!

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

You keep using this word, "Freedom." I do not think it means what you think it means. Destroying net neutrality is not “Restoring Internet Freedom.” In Fact, destroying net neutrality is a violation of our constitutional right; it would undermine this nation's capacity to protect free speech.

Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Nancy Berggren

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

It is my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action, and believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: * deliberately throttling internet traffic * squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps * misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet * giving privileged treatment to companies they own * strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet * avoiding real competition at all costs Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.\n\nI also believe that this submission process should be revised, as I view having to publicly disclose my personal information in order to have a say in my democracy as an abhorrent attempt to stifle my civic duty to engage.

Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
MAX DILLEY

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Vincenzo Pavone

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
James Vanderburg

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Manny

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Roger Danforth

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am a small business owner and I am concerned that these actions will negatively affect competition and eventually increase my costs as a customer of the large ISP's. I can not run my business without internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

I strongly support net neutrality.  You speak of reducing government control of the internet by reducing regulations but you do not say that your proposal gives more control to Corporations.  The FCCs duty is to protect the Consumer, not Corporations.  The FCC should protect net neutrality.  Do not give more power and control to Corporations which control access to free-flowing information.  Internet access is a necessity and consumers fair access to it should be protected by the FCC.  Internet access should not be monopolized, price-jacked or chosen by internet providers.  Do not allow service provider Corporations (which already have a monopoly or limited competition in many areas) prioritize certain distributors over others for their own profits. Please keep net neutrality.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I strongly oppose eliminating the net neutrality rules already in place. ISPs are a monopoly (I have only one broadband choice), and therefore require regulation to prevent them from taking advantage of  their monopoly status. I realize that the industry has already bought and paid for these changes, but I had to add my voice to the millions who oppose this action.

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them. Citizens of the United States deserve to have fair, open, competitive use of the resource that is the World Wide Web.  The open playground for innovation has been key in the growth of the US economy over the last 20 years. Do not let the interests of sole business with large pockets stifle the collective spirit of this free nation.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Matthew Schaitel

I was a small-town public library director for 20 years, and watched computers enter our lives. It is abundantly clear to me that the Internet has become an essential utillity for everyday employment and personal needs.  I oppose deregulation of Internet access because it privileges wealthy corporate entities and harms US citizens.  Deregulation would widen the digital divide.  Designation of the Internet as a utility helps strengthen democracy.

I stand firmly against this proposal. Preserving net neutrality is imperative to the free market. Allowing telecom companies to have it their way would have massive repercussions that would affect everyone, from competitors to consumers - sans, of course, telecom companies and anti-neutrality politicians. Without the Title II rules and regulations, telecom corporations are given unchecked power and control over their customers' Internet access; there would be nothing to stop Comcast, for example, from throttling competitors by placing additional charges on their services or blocking their sites entirely in order to extort money from their customers. The American consumer stands to gain absolutely nothing by supporting this proposal. It is anti-neutrality, anti-free market, and anti-consumer. It does not promote the rights of consumers, it gives telecom companies to ability to unfairly crush competition whilst shafting their customers in the process. As such, I strongly disapprove of this proposal, and urge the FCC to reconsider its priorities in promoting corporate interests as opposed to those of its constituents.

It is my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action, and believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: * deliberately throttling internet traffic * squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps * misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet * giving privileged treatment to companies they own * strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet * avoiding real competition at all costs Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

My internet went out late Saturday night, after contacting Comcast they set up an appt for Tuesday for a tech to come out. Sunday morning while letting the dogs out I realized the outage was due to a branch taking out the wires leading to the house. After contacting Comcast again at 9am, since the wire was across my whole back yard & my home security was linked to the internet, they stated they would dispatch a tech out immediately because this was of high priority. I even got the order #041777952. At 4 pm I called back to get eta of the tech & was told they were coming out Tuesday & they don't do same day appt. I asked why I was promised same day appts the guy stated 'The other girl probably just told you what you wanted to hear'. I immediately asked to speak to a supervisor Oscar empl #9962 who also stated they don't do same day appt & it would have to wait. He also stated I would have to 'prove' that the service had been out to get any kind of credit for having no service even though they knew at their end there was an issue with connection. I addressed with him the security system failure & hazard of the wire across the back yard & what to do with it considering having dogs that needed to be let out, he made a snide comment about the dogs under his breath but wouldn't repeat what he had said and told me 'nevermind'.

I am a small business owner.  I am very much in favor of a free market.  However, the internet itself has become a necessity of living a productive life in the first world.  \n\nA vast majority of entry level jobs require internet access just to begin the application process, from grocery stores to fast food restaurants to factories.  Because of this, the evolution of the internet in its current state has determined that it is a telecommunications service at its core and should be treated as such.  The President himself uses the internet as a telecommunications service, because that is what social media is.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most people living in the so-called U.S. only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Ruddy

I very strongly oppose this proceeding. Far from restoring internet freedom, this would effectively gut net neutrality. Preserving net neutrality is imperative to the free market. Allowing telecom companies to have it their way would have massive repercussions that would affect everyone, from competitors to consumers. Without the Title II rules and regulations, telecom corporations are given unchecked power and control over their customers' Internet access; there would be nothing to stop Comcast, for example, from throttling competitors by placing additional charges on their services or blocking their sites entirely in order to extort money from their customers. The American consumer stands to gain absolutely nothing by supporting this proposal. It is anti-freedom, anti-free market, anti-small-business, and anti-consumer. It does not promote the rights of consumers, it gives telecom companies to ability to unfairly crush competition whilst shafting their customers in the process. As such, I strongly disapprove of this proposal, and urge the FCC to reconsider its priorities in promoting corporate interests as opposed to those of its constituents.

It is my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action, and believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: * deliberately throttling internet traffic * squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps * misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet * giving privileged treatment to companies they own * strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet * avoiding real competition at all costs Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.
I oppose reversing the FCC's Title II classification of ISPs. Reversing Title II will benefit only the largest ISPs and violates the principle of an open Internet. Thank you!

Paragraph 82 regarding throttling internet contentions is preposterous. I am in the belief that whatever internet speed a consumer is paying for should not be intentionally altered in this way under any circumstance. 

I disagree with the notion of ISPs being allowed to collect/distribute user information.

On a more general note: Information on the internet is not inherently equal, in the case of entertainment sites compared to educational data bases as one example, but because of the volume of information on the internet I do not believe there is any robust, reliable, or accurate way for ISPs or any organizations to make this determination. In other words, I cannot support any ruling that lets any entity to regulate how (in the terms that the overthrowing of this policy will allow) information is to be distributed. 

One last reiteration: Information should be treated equally.

As a law librarian, I strongly believe in the importance of an neutral internet and urge you to reject this effort to weaken the FCC's current net neutrality rules. 

Equal access to information is a fundamental principle of the Internet. Net neutrality ensures that everyone - whether a researcher, attorney, self-represented litigant, small business owner, or student - has a consistent and reliable way of accessing information online.   The nature of the web also gives the public the ability to find critical information on current events and politics, enabling more informed participation in the democratic process.  Allowing any broadband providers to stifle, throttle, or divert consumers to sites based purely on which company can pay the highest fee only adds to the information bias problems we already see on the web and allows those companies to shape and mold public discourse to their own ends.  

Additionally, it increases the chances that particular companies will create monopolies by using their deep pockets to divert users away from smaller competitors to remove competition.  That influence should be the result of effective advertising of quality goods and services, NOT cutting off access to competitors.  

The FCC conducted a long and thorough rulemaking to come up with the current net neutrality rules, and the rules must be preserved.

Please do not vote to enact this regulation.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC should retain the ability to regulate the Internet as a public utility under the provisions of Title II. ISPs have shown they are willing and able to abuse customers and shake them down for every last dollar they can. Most consumers lack choice in their ISP as well, with many only having one or two wired options. Telecommunications companies have been gearing up for the repeal of all net neutrality as they gobble up content creators in an attempt to create a vertical market. They also continue to purchase smaller regional ISPs, which further erodes consumer choice. I ask that the FCC protect net neutrality for the sake of all American Internet users.

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

I support the use of Title II as well as current net neutrality rules that are in place. These ensure a fair & open internet for all. What exists is currently in the best interest of the American people. The only reason to try to repeal this is due to political ideology (which is childish), or to allow ISPs to take advantage of Americans, charge additional fees, censor, paid prioritization, or restrict access. We already don't have a choice in ISPs for high speed internet in this country (due to government granted monopolies and collusion within the ISPs themselves - why don't you legislate THAT problem?). I realize that these massive companies are funneling money into our politicians (and Pai doesn't realize he doesn't work for Verizon anymore and his boss(es) are the citizens of this country) so they can take advantage of all of us but it would be nice if for once our government stood up for what's in the best interest of the American people. You just sold us out by allowing ISPs to sell off our personal internet history, how much more damage are you trying to do to us for your own personal gain? There has been no harm from implementing these rules and this is not an example of  unnecessary "government regulation". It is working as intended to the benefit of all Americans and should be left as is.

Ajit Pai fundamentally misunderstands the function of the FCC. Part of the purpose of the FCCs rules are to create protections for citizens. Removing regulations on broadband providers, who in most regions operate a monopoly, are removing protections for citizens from those monopolies.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

I have worked as a web developer since 2008, and I vehemently oppose this effort to weaken net neutrality rules. I do not see any way in which it substantially protects consumer interests, or online businesses' fair access to customers. Instead, it allows ISP's to unfairly pick and choose which content to privilege on their networks, limiting the ability of online businesses to compete with ISPs' own content, as well as compete with online businesses that can afford to cut deals. This proposal deeply favors businesses with more money, the ISP's themselves (many of which have their own content networks that they desperately would like to give preferential treatment), and will therefore stifle online competition, innovation, and consumer choice. I can't put it any more simply than that.

Without strong net neutrality rules, we have already seen numerous abuses by ISP's that were clearly anti-competitive and anti-consumer. A particularly egregious example is in 2012 when Comcast wanted to make it so their own Xbox app didn't count against their customers' data caps, but competing apps would. This is a clear example of company controlling both the content and distribution network using their power to stifle competition unfairly. It is no surprise that consumers got fed up and asked for ISPs to be classified under Title II.

In our country, the big cable ISPs are natural monopolies, and represent most home internet traffic because they are the fastest and most reliable providers in most areas and do not compete in each others' territory and lobby local governments extensively to stifle competition. If you do away with net neutrality rules, most Americans will no longer have access to a free and open internet where all content is accessible and all businesses compete fairly. Please preserve the wonderful and democratic nature of the internet for future generations.

Thank you,
William Makley

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. The FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and to allow internet providers to determine what content is allowed on the internet. I am against this action. Allowing internet providers to be the gatekeepers of the public internet will increase censorship, decrease opportunities and destroy our freedoms. Among the most cherished of our liberties is our freedom of speech. The internet providers should be regulated in the same way that our telephone lines and our printed mediums are regulated -- with the idea that our freedoms will never be infringed. These public utilities should continue to be overseen by the agency that will enforce the public interests and this includes protecting our freedom of speech and freedom of commerce. By removing the restrictions of net neutrality, internet providers will have free reign to censor competitors through price controls, to censor its own customers through exclusions of content and to censor the very idea of our freedom of speech through their own actions. Internet providers have already put these ideas into practice through actions that are similar in nature to these. They have lobbied governments to restrict community-based internet, they have required Netflix and other content providers to pay higher prices for internet access, they have redirected domain lookup results to their own websites, they have implemented the idea of "bandwidth caps" and they have stated that they intend to do more than this. The internet is a required utility for any 21st century business. The very notion that a new startup -- such as Sears -- could operate solely by mail-order would be laughable today. In order for America to proceed into modern times and to compete successfully against the global economy, we must have a fair and open internet free from any constraints. This necessarily requires oversight of the internet providers and the prompt enforcement of our liberties -- the greatest of all is our freedom of speech.

If Ajit Pai is allowed to do this, he will be literally destroying the internet as a fair and level playing field. You wouldn't allow the US Post Office to intentionally slow service to, or outright refuse to deliver letters or packages to someone based on where that package was purchased, the contents, or where it was going, so why is it acceptable to let Internet Service Providers do exactly that?

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them. Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to: * Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees" * Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds) * Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating") They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way. Please don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

You are once again attempting to walk us blindly into a dark and troublesome future. There is no reason for me to chronicle the many, many examples of how the "free market" ISPs control have failed the american people time and time again. Being the FCC, there is no doubt in my mind that the dubious history of US ISPs is well known by you. I also have no doubt that an uncountable number of american citizens have pointed out the shame you should be feeling for your current actions. I am sure the effort is wasted on you. My suggestions to you regarding proceeding 17-108, dubiously called "Restoring Internet Freedom", is to scrap it in its current form. It is, for the most part, unusable. Instead, I would include provisions that require, or seek to foster, true competition between ISPs. The mafia-esque manner in which they have carved up this country can in no way be considered competition. Open and fair competition between websites and companies using the internet should be made sacred, contrary to the current attempt to allow ISPs to tax growing companies and small business for the privilege of joining the "express lane". In addition, ISP pricing transparency is a necessity. I fear for us, I really do. What you are doing cannot be forgiven. I hope that you have it within you to reconsider. However, this is only the opinion of a concerned citizen. I'm not sure how much that will truly mean to you.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Edward C. Halbach III

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
JD Retzer

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
John Cogley

Eliminating Title II classification and rolling back net neutrality will allow ISPs to charge both consumers and content providers heavily to be consumed on their networks.  This will harm consumers in two ways:  ISPs will charge consumers more;  content providers will be forced to charge consumers more to cover the costs of paying ISPs.  Allowing throttling, blocking, and paid privilege from the ISPs can in no way make the marketplace more competitive and better for anyone involved except the ISPs themselves.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

It is my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action, and believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: * deliberately throttling internet traffic * squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps * misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet * giving privileged treatment to companies they own * strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet * avoiding real competition at all costs Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

As an executive at a software company, I am strongly opposed to the elimination of net neutrality rules.  Throttling and fee-based traffic prioritization has significant negative impacts both on early stage businesses and consumers.   It creates an anti-competitive environment in which established players with funding available to pay to prioritize their traffic are able to reach audiences far more effectively than startups small businesses.  Given that, as of 2015, small to medium sized software firms accounted for 7 percent of US GDP  and 11.5 percent of private sector employment in the US (https://www.selectusa.gov/software-and-information-technology-services-industry-united-states), any move which raises the cost of market entry and increases the difficulty of disruptive innovation is likely to result in wide ranging, negative economic impacts.  \n\nFurthermore, the innovations that result from such innovative economic activity deliver enormous benefits to consumers  in the forms of increased choice and access to solutions and services that meet the changing needs of a digital society.  To suggest that stifling innovative small businesses somehow protects consumers is fallacious at best and dangerous at worst as the rollback of network neutrality rules will dramatically reduce consumer choice and access to innovative product offerings from small businesses while at the same time hamstringing one of the most rapidly growing and important industries in the nation.

I'm writing to ask that FCC Chairman Pai reconsider his intention to undermine Net Neutrality, an action that would transform the internet as we have known it from its inception. His actions would create fast and slow lanes of access, create tiers of access based on an American's ability to pay, and allow ISPs not to serve content they deem too controversial.

These restrictions, if allowed, would essentially undermine free expression itself. As Americans, we have a constitutional right to free speech. I hope the Chairman will not favor the profits of large cable companies over the rights of all Americans to full and unfettered access to the Internet.

Thank you.

My state, West Virginia, suffers from some of the worst broadband access in the country. Eliminating these protections will only drown them in worse conditions with access to cyber-infrastructure. Having been ruled by monopolies for decades, cutting more consumer protections is a spit in the face to the so proposed 'freedom,' which is given to companies such as Comcast, Frontier, and Time Warner Cable-Charter, who have monopolized and enforced agreed upon districting that has lead to no competition in our state. With no options to promote market competition, these will simply help line the pockets of the companies, that have ensured no competition, so that they can maximize profits over consumer wants and needs when gaining access to internet services. Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. With this proposement, I fear that we will simply be walking back on ourselves, and allow the companies that provide these services to believe it is right again. Thank you for your time.

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Alec Arroyo

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Noah Castro

As someone who works in the tech industry, there is NOTHING about rolling back net neutrality protections that promotes freedom. The only freedom it encourages is the freedom for ISPs to take money from any company that conducts business over the internet. This will destroy countless small businesses, who will be unable to compete with larger tech companies that can pay for access. Can the FCC please protect consumers and small businesses and keep net neutrality in place?

The D.C. Circuit’s decision in the Verizon case dealt a huge blow to the open Internet.

Right now there is no one protecting Internet users from ISPs that block or discriminate against websites, applications or services. Companies like Verizon will now be able to block or slow down any website, application or service they like. And they’ll be able to create tiered pricing structures with fast lanes for those who can afford the tolls and slow lanes for everyone else.

This decision will be devastating for independent entrepreneurs, impoverished individuals, and small content creators. The internet is a necessary communication tool in today's society. For people who work online, they may now have to decide between paying for fast-lane service and groceries. This is wrong. 

It’s time for the new FCC leadership to correct the agency’s past mistakes and to reassert the agency’s clear authority over our nation’s communications infrastructure. To preserve the open Internet, the FCC must reclassify broadband Internet access as a telecommunications service.

Use your authority to establish a solid legal footing for the vital policies and protections this court decision threatens.

I'm writing because I am concerned about the throttling and purely profit-driven "data-caps".   There is no reason to throttle something when there is not a shortage of something.  I download games (that I have legally purchased from Steam and Origin) and these games are sometimes upwards of 50 GB each.  It's restricting my access not only to entertainment but to documentaries and youtube lessons for my grad school classes.  Allowing ISPs which already is an oligopoly MORE freedom is not the best thing for consumers.  It's the best thing for the companies.

Net neutrality is a good thing. Internet should be regulated like a utility. There are not enough service providers (ie competition) in the geographical markets for the companies to regulate themselves through free market principles. This proposal is bad. Do not enact this proposal.

I am opposed to the Restoring Internet Freedom act. Priority lanes will not only hurt competition but it increases costs for consumers. These costs are never absorbed by the companies that are providing a service as this affects the bottom line. These costs will be passed on to the consumer. To put such a name as "Restoring Internet Freedom" on this bill is misleading.

The internet should be a guaranteed basic right to all Americans because it is becoming largely necessary to participate in our society. It is because of this that Internet Service Providers should be classified as public utilities since internet access is becoming just as necessary as electricity and water.

Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. Thanks for reading my comment.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
cheryl

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

These "1-click outrage" submissions are pretty ridiculous.  Anyone who understands the Internet (this obviously includes the FCC) understands the importance of Net Neutrality for consumer privacy (vs deep packet inspection), and for supporting innovation by maintaining an even playing field for new businesses.  They understand that Internet access is a defacto requirement for financial and professional activities.  They understand that most markets do not have a choice of ISPs.  They understand that introducing "a fast lane and a super-fast lane" or "a metered lane and an unmetered lane" are the same as introducing a slow lane; a penalized lane.  I'm sure Chairman Pai understands this perfectly well too, despite his public comments.\n\nIt would be nice if federal agencies worked to protect our more than 3 million people, rather than a handful of rich corporations looking for innovative ways to use those 3 million people to become richer.

It has come to my attention that the FCC is once again contemplating the reversal of net neutrality rules. I am staunchly opposed to any action that would rescind or otherwise lessen net neutrality protections. Under the principles of net neutrality, popular sites like Reddit, Netflix, and Facebook have flourished. These provisions of net neutrality do not harm anyone. Further, ISPs are corporations, not public entities. I do not have faith that they will act in the best interest of the American people, and believe that they will instead act in the interest of pursuing greater profits. We've dealt with this before, and nothing new has changed (except maybe a new president), so we should not be dealing with this again.\n\nBottom line: do not rescind net neutrality.

I am a venture capital investor in technology startups. The success of America’s startup ecosystem depends on an open Internet — including enforceable net neutrality rules that ensure big cable companies can’t discriminate against startups. 

If net neutrality regulations are dismantled, it’s difficult to predict exactly how ISPs will behave, but we do know how they behave relative to another communication network technology- cable television. These same companies control cable TV, and charge both sides of the network. On one side of the network, they only carry content providers who pay them large sums of cash and equity, and on the other side of the network, they offer more channels to customers who pay higher rates than others. Were the current net neutrality rules against blocking, throttling and paid prioritization of data to be lifted, ISPs would have the ability to determine which content providers can have access to their networks (as they do now with cable TV channels), and what content its consumers have access to (as they do now with cable TV packages).

Without net neutrality, the incumbents who provide access to the Internet would be able to pick winners or losers in the market. They could impede traffic from startup services in order to favor their own services or established competitors. The unavoidable result will be stifled innovation, as there would no longer exist a monetary incentive to launch an internet startup, and without a monetary incentive there would be no ability to attract investment capital.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.
