It is my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So, to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.\n\nPlease preserve the foundation of the free and open internet and leave net neutrality protections in place.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Travis Beckham

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Carly Nacmanie

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules. I am FIRMLY against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.\n\nMany places in the US have only one available ISP, or one "real" choice for broadband internet. Regulating the ISP like a utility makes sense when there is no meaningful competition. If you truly want to promote innovation, then promote competition between ISPs by breaking up Comcast and Spectrum and allowing municipalities to create their own ISPs.

Net neutrality is a must for the health of the American Tech sector. Many startups depend on it so they can compete with giants like Facebook and Amazon. To get rid of net neutrality would mean a stifling if innovation and a smaller economy.

I am FOR the Net Neutrality rules, and AGAINST the FCC Chairman's intention to reverse these rules, for several reasons:

1. Increased competition: If everyone is on equal, neutral footing, competition is high. However, if a monopoly can leverage its size, it can prevent competition from every growing. This is happening with AT&T and Comcast sueing Google Fiber to prevent competition. Without Net Neutrality, Comcast and AT&T wouldn't even have to sue Google Fiber, they could threaten Google's business by slowing down Google services until Google does what they want. 

2. It prevents monopolies: If a Internet Service Provider (ISP) can control the speed of websites, they can degrade the performance of their competitors in order to A) Blackmail them for money, or B) Promote their own service. This happened in 2014 when Comcast throttled Netflix until Netflix paid Comcast for the same speeds everyone else was already getting.

3. We can't currently vote with our wallets: In theory, Capitalism should sort this out, and consumers would choose with their wallets if they wanted Net Neutrality. The reality is that most people have 1 or 2 ISPs, max, that they can choose from. If neither are Net Neutral, consumers have no choice. 

We need our politicians to stand in our best interests. If you get rid of Net Neutrality, ISPs will leverage their monopolies to hurt consumers, charging them more for fewer options. 

Please KEEP Net Neutrality.

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Pamela

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

I oppose reversing the FCC's Title II classification of ISPs. Reversing Title II will benefit only the largest ISPs and violates the principle of an open Internet. Thank you!

Network Neutrality and common carrier based communication in the U.S. dates back to 1860 with the telegraph. The internet should adhere to our American tradition by leaving Internet Service Providers classified as a Title II common carrier service. The chairman's claim of lack of investment in broadband when ISPs are classified under Title II does not resonate with the reality of what capital expenditures were from 1996 - 2001. Furthermore, from 2002 -2012 CAPEX for broadband showed little to no growth while there were no enforceable Net Neutrality regulations on the FCC books. When Open Internet principles were codified in 2010/11 we saw a mild increase in CAPEX. However those were overruled in 2014. Looking at the history of Broadband CAPEX, history shows more broadband investment gains when ISPs are classified as Title II.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them. Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to: * Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees" * Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds) * Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating") They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way. Please don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Jesse Pitts

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Ann

Chairman Pai says it's "basic economics" that regulations slow business. Chairman Pai, please come and take an Econ class. I'm a professor: I can hook you up.

Monopolists like cable companies increase profits by reducing service provision. The way to combat that is by regulation. When there isn't sufficient competition, you maximize total surplus through regulation. 

The public interest is best served by classifying the internet as a utility. Any other arguments are simply lies and distortions designed rig the market in favor of the monopolist. As an economist, I'm not opposed to corporate profits, but I AM opposed to excess profits and deadweight loss. Please do your job and regulate this industry in the public interest.
I wish to pledge my support for the principles of net neutrality and an open and free internet

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I would prefer to have no internet than have my privacy sold to the highest bidder. Why are we tearing down walls we worked so hard to put up? Stop trying to change the borders, it's called a Personal Computer not a Public Computer.
Christian

Please do not go back and gut the Net Neutrality rules that were put in place a few years ago. I do not want the internet to be protectionist where incumbent websites and web service providers can afford to pay ISPs for prioritized or rate exempted traffic and newcomers cannot. The internet needs to open to allow new businesses to thrive and not just have the existing ones there, stagnant.

Please keep net neutrality intact. The internet should be treated like a utility with strong prohibitions against internet providers blocking content, slowing down traffic, or creating “fast lanes” for owners who pay more. Net neutrality provides protections to startups, small business, libraries, and educational organizations and also prevents ISPs from controlling access to internet content. If the principles that govern net neutrality had not been in place for the last 15 years, businesspersons would have been discouraged from creating the broad range of online services that has earned billions of dollars and created countless American jobs, both necessities for a healthy economy.

In my state (New Hampshire) Internet Service Providers (mainly Comcast) have monopolies. Much of NH is rural and has limited access to broadband, but even in the populated areas of the state there is generally only one choice for broadband internet. In the largest city in the state, Manchester, the only ISP that can provide service with broadband speed (25mbps download) internet is Comcast.  It costs $75/month (before taxes and fees) for that 25mbps service. Fairpoint is able to provide 3mbps for $49, though that falls short of what the FCC considers "Broadband". ISPs are already taking advantage of consumers because they know they have no competition. If net neutrality is not preserved we, as consumers, will end up paying more money for worse service. And we can't take our business elsewhere because there's only one company that offers Broadband speed internet, and in many places NH Broadband isn't even available. 

As an IT professional I urge the FCC to support Net Neutrality. Also please consider verifying the vast number of duplicate opposition filings, I bet if the FCC mailed letters addressed to the people who supposedly wrote those comments they would not get a response. 

-Ryan

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Please defend Net Neutrality. Practically every piece of our culture has been commercialized. Educational and non-profit institutions and the open internet are few of the last level playing grounds in our culture. It is vital to maintain net neutrality to protect citizens of all classes from monopolizing corporations making a profit. Please stand up for fair and free access to information. The stability of our society depends on it. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Emmy Thelander

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Austin Cobb

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.

The internet is a utility, and as such its equitable access should be regulated by the government. I strongly oppose Chairman Pai's proposal to repeal "Obama-era internet regulations."
I stand firmly against this proposal. Preserving net neutrality is imperative to the free market.  This proceeding would hurt small business and the consumer.

Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network.  I’m worried that the protections that are in place will be weakened if we change the way they’re enforced. I would support a new regulation style if it guarantees the same or better protections, but not if we lose any. Thanks for reading my comment.

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Robert

Net Neutrality is crucial to protect consumers and small businesses.  If I run a new video website like netflix, I should not have to pay my own internet and pay comcast for users to access my system.  Also Internet should not be throttled based on content.  non-net neutrality is Monopolistic and bad for the majority.

This proposal would remove regulations that are absolutely necessary! ISPs have government-granted monopolies in almost every area of the country. I live in a major metropolitan area and I have TWO options for internet: Comcast and CenturyLink.

If the consumers were capable of choosing between 10-15 providers, then the market would naturally not do something epically unfriendly to consumers like throttling Netflix traffic, charging more for access to some sites, or blackmailing content providers into striking deals for faster delivery.

As it stands now, consumers will either have to take it on the chin and pony up the cash for every new cool thing they find on the internet, or start lobbying hard for municipal internet and kick the private sector to the curb.

I am appalled at the FCC's decision to go against the will of the people and cement itself as a corporate puppet. The will of the people will be heard. Failure to listen will bring on litigation and the people's ire.

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Jason Stadeli

Here we go again.  After working so hard in assuring net neutrality became reality, I see it is now under attack once again.  Neutrality is for citizens and our economy, not for huge broadband corporations.  These corporations have continued their M&A activity as profits continue to soar. Please ensure the web is a utility and is regulated as such for the citizens of this country.

Commissioners: Please keep net neutrality as it is. Internet service provides a necessity like any other utility: water, power, etc. Telecom’s ability to restrict web traffic and add fees onto already bloated bills would pose a hardship to our family, who use the internet for work and academic pursuits, as well as household needs. ISP’s restricting content while favoring theirs, and intrusion of privacy, pose the other serious concerns. This proposed change does anything but restore freedom for the public, as it would further limit advancement for many people. Nonprofits and startup corporations/businesses would suffer as well, thus inhibiting competition and in turn negatively affecting consumer choice and pricing. Our vital but struggling libraries and schools with their limited funding present more victims and we depend on them so much! To compete globally, all of our United States citizenry and its public services should have equal access to our version of the web. Communication tools benefit the good of our country, and such decisions should be weighed in that favor. Thank you for your time.

I was recently informed that Chairman Pai plans to repeal net neutrality regulations, and I urge those of you at the FCC to prevent this at all costs. I find it repulsive that this initiative has been given the misleading title of, "Restoring Internet Freedom For All Americans." Net neutrality is what makes the internet free, in terms of universal access. Allowing corporations to force people to pay more to access premium websites creates devastating economic barriers, and thus makes the internet less free. The internet plays a crucial role in everyone's lives, and it is important that it remains accessible to all Americans, rich or poor. Ending net neutrality would increase costs for small businesses that draw customers with free wifi. These costs could easily make free wifi no longer feasible for such companies; their profits would see a decrease, or they could even go out of business, leaving countless employees without jobs. In private homes everywhere, families who can't afford a higher cost for premium websites may lose access to social media, through which they contact family and friends in other states. Students who can't afford premium internet sites could lose access to valuable research otherwise unavailable to them at their campus library. Sites that everyone uses in their daily lives, like YouTube, or Twitter, could only be available to the elite members of society. The beauty of the internet lies in its accessibility. It lies in the fact that small town musicians can make their music available to the whole world. It lies in the fact that film students can upload their creation, for free, to a site where their grandmother in another state can see it. It lies in the internet's ability to bring together families otherwise separated by oceans. The internet has granted Americans more freedom than they ever could have imagined thirty years ago. Countries that fear their people's freedom, like North Korea or China, place restrictions on their citizens' internet use. If the FCC allows corporations to place financial barriers and restrictions on the internet, our government is no better than those countries that treat freedom like a disease. The repeal of net neutrality only benefits the CEOs and executives that will line their pockets with the profits from helpless Americans. If you truly care for the freedom of all Americans, I implore you to keep net neutrality regulations in place.

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

Do not listen to those "copy paste" , Obama outrage remarks. Those comments are either fraudulent, coerced or ignorant. Large telecommunications networks are here to stay and will always push out small rural ISP's, regulation or not. The fact that the passing of this regulation is causing such an obvious push back from telecoms is proof that title II classification is doing its job. Reversing this ruling is a mistake and those pushing for it in the comments are frauds or unwitting pawns to a larger agenda. Title II or in English "COMMON CARRIER" classification IS the classification of an ISP. Anything less only serves to increase MARGINS and PROFITS at the EXPENCE of QUALITY and SERVICE.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

The internet needs to keep the utility designation. I have kids in school and they have been issued Chromebooks that they need to do their homework on. As I also have a job, I can't cart them around to "free wifi" places every day after school. Their schools also send their grades and important information online. Every few weeks, I need to "view" their progress online or they call me to ask why I'm not keeping up with the kids. I NEED the internet for the kids to do their school work and to keep in touch with the school. \nAs long as I have school age kids, the internet is a utility in my home as much as heat and lighting are. Without it, my kids WILL get after school detention for not being able to access their Chromebooks during non-school hours.

It's my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

Protect Net Neutrality. Net neutrality is the principle that all Internet traffic should be treated equally. I believe in this statement, and believe that equal access to equally-treated internet resources should be a right protected by the Federal government and the States. I do not support any policy-making or makers who would dismantle this right, either incrementally or wholly. 

As an artist and a writer, who uses the internet daily to promote his work, the equitable and fair treatment of the pathways for information allow me to share my ideas and build an audience unobstructedly; net neutrality is central to the experience of the public good as well, who, rather than funneled and controlled, enjoy the same opportunity to come across my work--or ignore it--as they go about their lives online. This means my audience can be judged to enjoy my work, discuss it, comment on it, even reject it, without difficulty or distortion, and relatively equally and without the obstructionism of a self-interested institution or state. Culture can be said to decide this, not ideology. 

As a citizen, I want to enjoy the same privilege to enjoy content, hate it, ignore it, or love it as I so choose. Any policy that would warp this experience is something I wholly oppose as a free-thinker and democratic citizen.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

* Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
* Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Sean Reilly

It has come to my attention that the FCC Chairman has stated his intention to reverse net neutrality and place large Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I object strongly to this action. As I understand it, part of this decision is based upon claims that net neutrality cost 5 billion in broadband investment, yet this claim is based on a single study that the chairman cited by the Free State Foundation, which received funding from various telecom lobbying groups to perform the study ($375k from NCTA and $280k from CTIA between 2010 and 2014, just to name a couple). I am a scientific professional and keenly aware of the risks of making sweeping changes based upon faulty or single-point data, particularly data, as in this case, the acquisition of which has been funded by the very bodies which stand to profit the most from such changes. In scientific terms, we call that a "conflict of interest". Further, from a political standpoint, net neutrality, contradictory to what is being claimed, is vitally necessary to the free market, particularly to small businesses. To reiterate: I am strongly against the chairman's plan to reverse net neutrality and I believe that such a reversal will result in the loss of vital growth and innovation.

To FCC and Chairman Pai,

The internet for the masses—in other words, what pretty much everyone has been using since the mid-90’s onward has been working fine.  The need for classifying ISP’s as title II’s came about due to the same ISP’s increasing avarice for charging subscribers more in spite of already making record profits.  The large ISP’s of USA essentially want to have their cake and eat it too:  charge the subscribers an arm and a leg, charge third-party sites for ‘first class’ peering, and make little to no improvements on their infrastructure.  Fever pitch was reached a few years ago and former Chairman Wheeler’s decision to lead the way to ‘permanently’ cement the Open Internet as forever open should not be altered.

Do not assume that revoking title II classifications will make ISP’s treat both customers and businesses fairly.  They won’t.

Again, the internet over the last two decades has been working fine.  However, regulation is now needed to ensure it stays that way.  Please do the right thing by DOING NOTHING.

Thank you,
Aaron

* Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
gemma

I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Justin Campo
